modules.title: Portfolio Strategy
modules.content: # Portfolio Strategy ## WHY This Matters Organizations don't have one AI opportunity—they have dozens. Each one competes for: - Budget - Talent - Leadership attention - Change capacity The enterprises that succeed don't just pick "good" AI projects. They build balanced portfolios that: - Deliver near-term value - Build long-term capability - Manage risk appropriately - Learn systematically Thinking at portfolio level is what separates operators from strategists. --- ## WHAT You Need to Know ### The AI Investment Horizon Framework ### The Portfolio Prioritization Matrix Evaluate initiatives across two dimensions: **Strategic Value:** - Revenue impact - Cost reduction - Competitive advantage - Customer experience improvement - Capability building **Execution Feasibility:** - Data readiness - Technical complexity - Organizational readiness - Resource availability - Risk level **Quick Wins**: Do now—high value, easy to execute **Big Bets**: Invest carefully—high value, requires significant effort **Maybe Later**: Consider if resources allow—lower value but achievable **Avoid**: Don't pursue—low value and difficult ### Portfolio Balance Indicators | Indicator | Healthy | Unhealthy | |-----------|---------|-----------| | Horizon mix | 70/20/10 | 100% H1 or 50%+ H3 | | Quick wins | 3-5 active | 0 or 10+ | | Big bets | 1-2 active | 0 or 5+ | | Risk distribution | Varied | All high or all low | | Learning rate | Weekly insights | Quarterly at best | ### The Value-Risk Tradeoff ### Learning Portfolio Management AI portfolios must generate learning, not just ROI: **Every initiative should answer questions:** - What did we learn about this use case? - What capability did we build? - What patterns can we reuse? - What should we do differently next time? **Structure for learning:** - Clear hypotheses before launch - Defined success metrics - Regular retrospectives - Knowledge capture and sharing ### The Anti-Patterns | Anti-Pattern | Problem | Solution | |--------------|---------|----------| | **Pilot purgatory** | Many pilots, nothing scales | Clear scale criteria, kill or scale decisions | | **Big bang syndrome** | All investment in one moonshot | Balanced portfolio with quick wins | | **Risk aversion** | Only safe bets, no innovation | Protected budget for H2/H3 experiments | | **Flavor of the month** | New priorities constantly | Stable investment thesis, regular reviews | | **Isolated initiatives** | No learning transfer | Portfolio-level governance and sharing | --- ## HOW to Apply This ### Exercise: Build Your AI Portfolio ### Portfolio Review Template ``` QUARTERLY PORTFOLIO REVIEW ━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━ PORTFOLIO HEALTH Active Initiatives: ___ Budget Allocated: $___ Budget Spent: $___ Team Capacity: ___% utilized Horizon Mix: H1: __% (target: 70%) H2: __% (target: 20%) H3: __% (target: 10%) INITIATIVE STATUS | Initiative | Status | Budget | Value Delivered | Learning | |------------|--------|--------|-----------------|----------| | | 🟢🟡🔴 | | | | | | 🟢🟡🔴 | | | | | | 🟢🟡🔴 | | | | DECISIONS NEEDED Scale: • [Initiative ready to scale] Kill: • [Initiative to stop] Pivot: • [Initiative to redirect] New: • [New investment to consider] KEY LEARNINGS What we learned this quarter: 1. 2. 3. Patterns to reuse: 1. 2. Mistakes to avoid: 1. 2. NEXT QUARTER PRIORITIES 1. 2. 3. ━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━ ``` ### Self-Check --- ## Up Next In **Module 6.4: Operating Models for AI**, you'll learn how to design the organizational structures, processes, and governance that enable AI to scale across the enterprise.

Portfolio Strategy

WHY This Matters

Organizations don't have one AI opportunity—they have dozens. Each one competes for:

  • Budget
  • Talent
  • Leadership attention
  • Change capacity

The enterprises that succeed don't just pick "good" AI projects. They build balanced portfolios that:

  • Deliver near-term value
  • Build long-term capability
  • Manage risk appropriately
  • Learn systematically

Thinking at portfolio level is what separates operators from strategists.

WHAT You Need to Know

The AI Investment Horizon Framework

The Portfolio Prioritization Matrix

Evaluate initiatives across two dimensions:

Strategic Value:

  • Revenue impact
  • Cost reduction
  • Competitive advantage
  • Customer experience improvement
  • Capability building

Execution Feasibility:

  • Data readiness
  • Technical complexity
  • Organizational readiness
  • Resource availability
  • Risk level

Quick Wins: Do now—high value, easy to execute Big Bets: Invest carefully—high value, requires significant effort Maybe Later: Consider if resources allow—lower value but achievable Avoid: Don't pursue—low value and difficult

Portfolio Balance Indicators

Indicator Healthy Unhealthy
Horizon mix 70/20/10 100% H1 or 50%+ H3
Quick wins 3-5 active 0 or 10+
Big bets 1-2 active 0 or 5+
Risk distribution Varied All high or all low
Learning rate Weekly insights Quarterly at best

The Value-Risk Tradeoff

Learning Portfolio Management

AI portfolios must generate learning, not just ROI:

Every initiative should answer questions:

  • What did we learn about this use case?
  • What capability did we build?
  • What patterns can we reuse?
  • What should we do differently next time?

Structure for learning:

  • Clear hypotheses before launch
  • Defined success metrics
  • Regular retrospectives
  • Knowledge capture and sharing

The Anti-Patterns

Anti-Pattern Problem Solution
Pilot purgatory Many pilots, nothing scales Clear scale criteria, kill or scale decisions
Big bang syndrome All investment in one moonshot Balanced portfolio with quick wins
Risk aversion Only safe bets, no innovation Protected budget for H2/H3 experiments
Flavor of the month New priorities constantly Stable investment thesis, regular reviews
Isolated initiatives No learning transfer Portfolio-level governance and sharing

sections.htmlContent:
The AI Investment Horizon Framework

The Portfolio Prioritization Matrix

Evaluate initiatives across two dimensions:

Strategic Value:

  • Revenue impact
  • Cost reduction
  • Competitive advantage
  • Customer experience improvement
  • Capability building

Execution Feasibility:

  • Data readiness
  • Technical complexity
  • Organizational readiness
  • Resource availability
  • Risk level

Quick Wins: Do now—high value, easy to execute Big Bets: Invest carefully—high value, requires significant effort Maybe Later: Consider if resources allow—lower value but achievable Avoid: Don't pursue—low value and difficult

Portfolio Balance Indicators

Indicator Healthy Unhealthy
Horizon mix 70/20/10 100% H1 or 50%+ H3
Quick wins 3-5 active 0 or 10+
Big bets 1-2 active 0 or 5+
Risk distribution Varied All high or all low
Learning rate Weekly insights Quarterly at best

The Value-Risk Tradeoff

Learning Portfolio Management

AI portfolios must generate learning, not just ROI:

Every initiative should answer questions:

  • What did we learn about this use case?
  • What capability did we build?
  • What patterns can we reuse?
  • What should we do differently next time?

Structure for learning:

  • Clear hypotheses before launch
  • Defined success metrics
  • Regular retrospectives
  • Knowledge capture and sharing

The Anti-Patterns

Anti-Pattern Problem Solution
Pilot purgatory Many pilots, nothing scales Clear scale criteria, kill or scale decisions
Big bang syndrome All investment in one moonshot Balanced portfolio with quick wins
Risk aversion Only safe bets, no innovation Protected budget for H2/H3 experiments
Flavor of the month New priorities constantly Stable investment thesis, regular reviews
Isolated initiatives No learning transfer Portfolio-level governance and sharing

concepts.definition:
Balance investments across three horizons:

**Horizon 1: Optimize (0-6 months)**
- Improve existing processes with AI
- Low risk, proven patterns
- Quick wins that build credibility
- Examples: Content generation, document processing, customer service automation

**Horizon 2: Extend (6-18 months)**
- Expand AI into new areas
- Moderate risk, emerging patterns
- Significant capability building
- Examples: Conversational commerce, predictive analytics, workflow automation

**Horizon 3: Transform (18+ months)**
- Fundamental business model innovation
- Higher risk, unproven patterns
- Strategic differentiation
- Examples: Agentic commerce, autonomous operations, new AI-native products

A healthy portfolio typically allocates:
- **70%** to Horizon 1 (optimize)
- **20%** to Horizon 2 (extend)
- **10%** to Horizon 3 (transform)

Every AI initiative sits on a value-risk curve:

**Low Risk / Low Value:**
- Internal productivity tools
- Back-office automation
- Non-customer-facing applications
- Limited scope/scale

**Medium Risk / Medium Value:**
- Customer-facing assistance (human backup)
- Recommendation systems
- Content generation with review
- Operational improvements

**High Risk / High Value:**
- Autonomous customer interactions
- Real-time decision systems
- Business model innovation
- Large-scale deployments

The portfolio question isn't "which has the best ROI?" but "what mix of risk/reward fits our strategy and capacity?"

modules.htmlContent:
Operating Models for AI

WHY This Matters

Individual AI projects can succeed with ad-hoc approaches. AI at scale cannot.

When AI moves from pilots to production, from one team to many, organizations need:

  • Clear ownership and accountability
  • Consistent standards and practices
  • Efficient resource allocation
  • Systematic learning and improvement
  • Appropriate risk management

The operating model is what makes AI scalable, sustainable, and safe. Without it, you get fragmented efforts, duplicated work, inconsistent quality, and ungovernable risk.

WHAT You Need to Know

Operating Model Components

The Organizational Models

Three primary patterns for organizing AI capability:

Model 1: Centralized (Center of Excellence)

Model 2: Federated (Hub and Spoke)

Model 3: Hybrid (Matrix) (Recommended)

Choosing the Right Model

Factor Favors Centralized Favors Federated Favors Hybrid
AI maturity Low Medium-High Medium
Org size Small-Medium Large Medium-Large
BU diversity Low High Medium
Talent availability Scarce Available Mixed
Regulation intensity High Low Medium

The Center of Excellence Model

For most enterprises starting their AI journey, a CoE is the right foundation:

Governance Design

Decision Type Who Decides Who Advises Who Executes
AI strategy & vision Executive sponsor CoE, BU leaders CoE
Investment allocation Steering committee CoE, Finance BU leaders
Standards & policies CoE Legal, Security, Risk CoE
Use case approval Tiered (see below) CoE, Risk BU teams
Vendor selection IT + CoE Procurement CoE
Incident response CoE + Risk Legal Response team

Tiered Use Case Approval:

Tier Risk Level Approver Review Requirements
1 Low (internal, non-critical) Manager Self-assessment
2 Medium (customer-facing, review) CoE CoE review
3 High (autonomous, sensitive) Steering committee Full governance review

Scaling Patterns

As AI matures, the operating model evolves:

Stage 1: Seed (0-6 months)

  • Small core team (2-4 people)
  • Focus on first pilots
  • Establish initial standards
  • Prove value

Stage 2: Grow (6-18 months)

  • Formal CoE structure
  • First production deployments
  • Training programs launched
  • Governance established

Stage 3: Scale (18-36 months)

  • Federated teams emerge
  • Self-service capabilities
  • Mature governance
  • Measured value delivery

Stage 4: Pervasive (36+ months)

  • AI embedded everywhere
  • CoE becomes strategic advisor
  • Continuous improvement
  • Industry leadership

Critical Success Factors

Factor Description Warning Signs
Executive sponsorship Active, visible support from C-suite AI buried in IT, no strategic priority
Clear ownership Unambiguous accountability "Everyone's responsibility" = nobody's
Funding model Sustainable investment approach Project-by-project begging
Talent strategy Build, buy, borrow plan Always short on skills
Change management Systematic adoption approach Tech deployed, nobody uses it

HOW to Apply This

sections.htmlContent:
Operating Model Components

The Organizational Models

Three primary patterns for organizing AI capability:

Model 1: Centralized (Center of Excellence)

Model 2: Federated (Hub and Spoke)

Model 3: Hybrid (Matrix) (Recommended)

Choosing the Right Model

Factor Favors Centralized Favors Federated Favors Hybrid
AI maturity Low Medium-High Medium
Org size Small-Medium Large Medium-Large
BU diversity Low High Medium
Talent availability Scarce Available Mixed
Regulation intensity High Low Medium

The Center of Excellence Model

For most enterprises starting their AI journey, a CoE is the right foundation:

Governance Design

Decision Type Who Decides Who Advises Who Executes
AI strategy & vision Executive sponsor CoE, BU leaders CoE
Investment allocation Steering committee CoE, Finance BU leaders
Standards & policies CoE Legal, Security, Risk CoE
Use case approval Tiered (see below) CoE, Risk BU teams
Vendor selection IT + CoE Procurement CoE
Incident response CoE + Risk Legal Response team

Tiered Use Case Approval:

Tier Risk Level Approver Review Requirements
1 Low (internal, non-critical) Manager Self-assessment
2 Medium (customer-facing, review) CoE CoE review
3 High (autonomous, sensitive) Steering committee Full governance review

Scaling Patterns

As AI matures, the operating model evolves:

Stage 1: Seed (0-6 months)

  • Small core team (2-4 people)
  • Focus on first pilots
  • Establish initial standards
  • Prove value

Stage 2: Grow (6-18 months)

  • Formal CoE structure
  • First production deployments
  • Training programs launched
  • Governance established

Stage 3: Scale (18-36 months)

  • Federated teams emerge
  • Self-service capabilities
  • Mature governance
  • Measured value delivery

Stage 4: Pervasive (36+ months)

  • AI embedded everywhere
  • CoE becomes strategic advisor
  • Continuous improvement
  • Industry leadership

Critical Success Factors

Factor Description Warning Signs
Executive sponsorship Active, visible support from C-suite AI buried in IT, no strategic priority
Clear ownership Unambiguous accountability "Everyone's responsibility" = nobody's
Funding model Sustainable investment approach Project-by-project begging
Talent strategy Build, buy, borrow plan Always short on skills
Change management Systematic adoption approach Tech deployed, nobody uses it

concepts.definition:
A complete AI operating model addresses five dimensions:

**1. Organizational Structure**
- Where does AI capability live?
- Who owns what?
- How do teams coordinate?

**2. Governance & Decision Rights**
- Who approves AI initiatives?
- Who sets standards?
- Who manages risk?

**3. Talent & Skills**
- What roles are needed?
- How is talent developed?
- Where is expertise centralized vs. distributed?

**4. Processes & Practices**
- How are AI projects delivered?
- How is quality assured?
- How is knowledge shared?

**5. Technology & Platforms**
- What infrastructure is shared?
- What tools are standard?
- How is data managed?

# Lab 12: Portfolio Prioritization

## Lab Overview

You can't do everything. In this lab, you'll evaluate a set of AI opportunities and build a prioritized portfolio that balances quick wins with strategic bets, immediate value with capability building.

**What you'll create:**
- Scored opportunity inventory
- Prioritization matrix visualization
- Balanced portfolio allocation
- Investment roadmap with resource plan

---

## Part 1: The Scenario (5 minutes)

### Context

You're the AI Strategy Lead for a $2B specialty retailer with:

- 200 stores across North America
- Strong e-commerce (45% of revenue)
- 12,000 employees
- Growing competition from pure-play e-commerce
- New CEO with AI as strategic priority

**Your resources:**
- Annual AI budget: $4M
- Current AI team: 6 FTEs (can hire 4 more)
- Executive sponsor: Chief Digital Officer
- Mandate: Show measurable impact in Year 1

### The Opportunity List

Leadership has identified 12 potential AI initiatives. Your job: prioritize them.

```
OPPORTUNITY INVENTORY
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

| # | Initiative | Domain | Brief Description |
|---|------------|--------|-------------------|
| 1 | Conversational Product Advisor | CX | AI assistant for product recommendations |
| 2 | Customer Service Automation | CX | AI handling Tier 1 support inquiries |
| 3 | Dynamic Pricing Engine | Merch | Real-time competitive price optimization |
| 4 | Demand Forecasting | Supply Chain | ML-based inventory prediction |
| 5 | Product Description Generation | Content | Automated PDP copy creation |
| 6 | Visual Search | CX | Shop by image on mobile app |
| 7 | Review Sentiment Analysis | Merch | Extract insights from customer reviews |
| 8 | Personalized Email Content | Marketing | Dynamic email personalization |
| 9 | Store Associate AI Assistant | Operations | In-store product knowledge tool |
| 10 | Fraud Detection Enhancement | Risk | AI layer on top of existing fraud rules |
| 11 | Returns Prediction | Supply Chain | Predict return likelihood before purchase |
| 12 | Agentic Commerce Readiness | CX | Prepare for AI shopping assistants |

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
```

sections.title: Part 1: The Scenario (5 minutes)
sections.content:
### Context

You're the AI Strategy Lead for a $2B specialty retailer with:

- 200 stores across North America
- Strong e-commerce (45% of revenue)
- 12,000 employees
- Growing competition from pure-play e-commerce
- New CEO with AI as strategic priority

**Your resources:**
- Annual AI budget: $4M
- Current AI team: 6 FTEs (can hire 4 more)
- Executive sponsor: Chief Digital Officer
- Mandate: Show measurable impact in Year 1

### The Opportunity List

Leadership has identified 12 potential AI initiatives. Your job: prioritize them.

```
OPPORTUNITY INVENTORY
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

| # | Initiative | Domain | Brief Description |
|---|------------|--------|-------------------|
| 1 | Conversational Product Advisor | CX | AI assistant for product recommendations |
| 2 | Customer Service Automation | CX | AI handling Tier 1 support inquiries |
| 3 | Dynamic Pricing Engine | Merch | Real-time competitive price optimization |
| 4 | Demand Forecasting | Supply Chain | ML-based inventory prediction |
| 5 | Product Description Generation | Content | Automated PDP copy creation |
| 6 | Visual Search | CX | Shop by image on mobile app |
| 7 | Review Sentiment Analysis | Merch | Extract insights from customer reviews |
| 8 | Personalized Email Content | Marketing | Dynamic email personalization |
| 9 | Store Associate AI Assistant | Operations | In-store product knowledge tool |
| 10 | Fraud Detection Enhancement | Risk | AI layer on top of existing fraud rules |
| 11 | Returns Prediction | Supply Chain | Predict return likelihood before purchase |
| 12 | Agentic Commerce Readiness | CX | Prepare for AI shopping assistants |

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
```

---

# Capstone Project: AI Analyst Certification

## Project Overview

Your capstone project demonstrates mastery of the complete AI Analyst curriculum. You'll identify a real business challenge, design an AI solution, build a working prototype, and present a comprehensive business case.

This project becomes the centerpiece of your professional portfolio—evidence of your AI operator capabilities.

---

## Project Options

### Option A: Enterprise AI Transformation

Design and prototype an AI initiative for a department or function.

**Deliverables:**
1. Current state analysis with process maps
2. AI opportunity assessment
3. Working AI assistant or automation prototype
4. ROI analysis and business case
5. Governance recommendations
6. Implementation roadmap

**Best for:** Those targeting enterprise roles or consulting

---

### Option B: AI-Enhanced Product/Service

Create an AI-powered feature or service offering.

**Deliverables:**
1. Market opportunity analysis
2. Product/service specification
3. Working prototype demonstrating core AI functionality
4. Pricing and go-to-market recommendations
5. Technical architecture overview
6. Scaling considerations

**Best for:** Those in product roles or entrepreneurship

---

### Option C: AI Operations Playbook

Create a comprehensive playbook for AI adoption in a specific domain.

**Deliverables:**
1. Domain analysis (industry, function, or use case type)
2. AI opportunity catalog (10+ specific applications)
3. Template library (prompts, workflows, assessments)
4. Best practices guide
5. Case studies (3+ documented examples)
6. Training curriculum outline

**Best for:** Those targeting training, enablement, or thought leadership

---

### Option D: Personal AI System

Build a comprehensive AI system for your own professional use.

**Deliverables:**
1. Personal workflow audit
2. AI tool ecosystem design
3. 3+ working AI assistants/automations
4. Prompt library (20+ tested prompts)
5. Quality and governance approach
6. Usage analytics and improvement plan

**Best for:** Individual contributors wanting to demonstrate hands-on skills

---

## Project Requirements

### All capstone projects must include:

**Phase 1 Application (AI Literacy)**
- [ ] Evidence of model/provider selection rationale
- [ ] Documented prompt engineering approach
- [ ] Cost analysis and optimization

**Phase 2 Application (Workflow Engineering)**
- [ ] Process documentation
- [ ] Task decomposition
- [ ] Quality gates and human handoffs

**Phase 3 Application (Implementation)**
- [ ] Working prototype (assistant, automation, or both)
- [ ] Testing documentation
- [ ] Deployment approach

**Phase 4 Application (Strategy & Economics)**
- [ ] Business case with ROI
- [ ] Stakeholder analysis
- [ ] Governance considerations

---

## Project Timeline

### Week 1: Foundation
- Select project option
- Define scope and objectives
- Conduct initial research
- Create project plan

**Checkpoint:** Project proposal (1 page)

### Week 2-3: Design & Analysis
- Complete current state analysis
- Design AI solution
- Draft business case
- Begin prototype development

**Checkpoint:** Design document + initial prototype

### Week 4-5: Build & Test
- Complete prototype
- Conduct testing
- Document learnings
- Refine business case

**Checkpoint:** Working prototype + test results

### Week 6: Polish & Present
- Finalize all deliverables
- Create presentation
- Prepare for questions
- Submit final package

**Final submission:** Complete capstone package

---

## Evaluation Rubric

### Technical Execution (30%)

| Criterion | 1 (Developing) | 3 (Proficient) | 5 (Exemplary) |
|-----------|----------------|----------------|---------------|
| **AI Design** | Basic prompts, single model | Well-designed prompts, appropriate model selection | Sophisticated prompt engineering, multi-model architecture |
| **Implementation** | Works with limitations | Solid functionality, handles edge cases | Robust, production-ready quality |
| **Testing** | Minimal testing | Systematic test plan | Comprehensive testing with iteration |

### Business Acumen (30%)

| Criterion | 1 (Developing) | 3 (Proficient) | 5 (Exemplary) |
|-----------|----------------|----------------|---------------|
| **Problem Definition** | Vague problem statement | Clear problem with context | Compelling problem with market/organizational insight |
| **Value Proposition** | Limited value articulation | Clear benefits identified | Quantified ROI with sensitivity analysis |
| **Feasibility** | Overlooks implementation challenges | Acknowledges key challenges | Comprehensive implementation roadmap |

### Process & Methodology (20%)

| Criterion | 1 (Developing) | 3 (Proficient) | 5 (Exemplary) |
|-----------|----------------|----------------|---------------|
| **Workflow Design** | Ad hoc approach | Structured methodology | Systematic process with quality gates |
| **Governance** | Risk not addressed | Basic risk awareness | Comprehensive governance framework |
| **Documentation** | Minimal documentation | Complete documentation | Exemplary documentation with rationale |

### Communication (20%)

| Criterion | 1 (Developing) | 3 (Proficient) | 5 (Exemplary) |
|-----------|----------------|----------------|---------------|
| **Presentation** | Hard to follow | Clear and organized | Compelling narrative, executive-ready |
| **Written Materials** | Basic writing | Professional quality | Publication-quality writing |
| **Visual Design** | Cluttered or basic | Clean and professional | Polished and impactful |

---

## Submission Package

### Required Components

1. **Executive Summary** (1-2 pages)
   - Problem statement
   - Solution overview
   - Key results and value
   - Recommendation

2. **Full Project Report** (10-20 pages)
   - All required deliverables for chosen option
   - Supporting analysis
   - Technical documentation

3. **Working Prototype**
   - Link to live assistant/automation
   - OR video demonstration
   - OR detailed walkthrough with screenshots

4. **Presentation Deck** (10-15 slides)
   - Executive-ready presentation
   - Speaking notes included

5. **Appendices**
   - Prompt library used
   - Test cases and results
   - Additional supporting materials

---

## Portfolio Guidance

### Showcasing Your Capstone

**LinkedIn/Professional profiles:**
- Feature 2-3 key metrics from your project
- Link to executive summary
- Describe the business problem and your solution

**Interviews:**
- Be ready to demo your prototype
- Prepare to discuss trade-offs and decisions
- Have metrics memorized

**Portfolio site (if applicable):**
- Create a case study format
- Include visuals from your project
- Show before/after comparisons

---

## Getting Help

### Resources Available
- AI Sandbox for prototype development
- Curriculum materials for reference
- Peer review opportunities
- Office hours with instructors

### Common Challenges

| Challenge | Approach |
|-----------|----------|
| Scope too big | Focus on demonstrating skills, not solving everything |
| Can't access real data | Use realistic synthetic data |
| Prototype limitations | Document what you'd do with more resources |
| Business case assumptions | Be explicit, show sensitivity analysis |

---

## Final Checklist

Before submitting, verify:

**Completeness**
- [ ] All required deliverables included
- [ ] All six phases represented
- [ ] Working prototype accessible
- [ ] Presentation deck complete

**Quality**
- [ ] Proofread and professional
- [ ] Technical accuracy verified
- [ ] Business logic sound
- [ ] Visual design polished

**Impact**
- [ ] Clear value proposition
- [ ] Metrics and evidence
- [ ] Actionable recommendations
- [ ] Portfolio-ready

---

## Congratulations!

Completing your capstone project marks your transition from AI learner to AI operator. You've built:

- **Technical skills** to work with AI systems effectively
- **Business acumen** to drive AI value in organizations
- **Strategic thinking** to navigate AI opportunities and risks
- **Practical experience** through hands-on projects

Welcome to the future of work. You're ready to operate it.

sections.title: Evaluation Rubric
sections.content:
### Technical Execution (30%)

| Criterion | 1 (Developing) | 3 (Proficient) | 5 (Exemplary) |
|-----------|----------------|----------------|---------------|
| **AI Design** | Basic prompts, single model | Well-designed prompts, appropriate model selection | Sophisticated prompt engineering, multi-model architecture |
| **Implementation** | Works with limitations | Solid functionality, handles edge cases | Robust, production-ready quality |
| **Testing** | Minimal testing | Systematic test plan | Comprehensive testing with iteration |

### Business Acumen (30%)

| Criterion | 1 (Developing) | 3 (Proficient) | 5 (Exemplary) |
|-----------|----------------|----------------|---------------|
| **Problem Definition** | Vague problem statement | Clear problem with context | Compelling problem with market/organizational insight |
| **Value Proposition** | Limited value articulation | Clear benefits identified | Quantified ROI with sensitivity analysis |
| **Feasibility** | Overlooks implementation challenges | Acknowledges key challenges | Comprehensive implementation roadmap |

### Process & Methodology (20%)

| Criterion | 1 (Developing) | 3 (Proficient) | 5 (Exemplary) |
|-----------|----------------|----------------|---------------|
| **Workflow Design** | Ad hoc approach | Structured methodology | Systematic process with quality gates |
| **Governance** | Risk not addressed | Basic risk awareness | Comprehensive governance framework |
| **Documentation** | Minimal documentation | Complete documentation | Exemplary documentation with rationale |

### Communication (20%)

| Criterion | 1 (Developing) | 3 (Proficient) | 5 (Exemplary) |
|-----------|----------------|----------------|---------------|
| **Presentation** | Hard to follow | Clear and organized | Compelling narrative, executive-ready |
| **Written Materials** | Basic writing | Professional quality | Publication-quality writing |
| **Visual Design** | Cluttered or basic | Clean and professional | Polished and impactful |

sections.title: Submission Package
sections.content:
### Required Components

1. **Executive Summary** (1-2 pages)
   - Problem statement
   - Solution overview
   - Key results and value
   - Recommendation

2. **Full Project Report** (10-20 pages)
   - All required deliverables for chosen option
   - Supporting analysis
   - Technical documentation

3. **Working Prototype**
   - Link to live assistant/automation
   - OR video demonstration
   - OR detailed walkthrough with screenshots

4. **Presentation Deck** (10-15 slides)
   - Executive-ready presentation
   - Speaking notes included

5. **Appendices**
   - Prompt library used
   - Test cases and results
   - Additional supporting materials
